image.altText: A close up shot of a police officer wearing blue plastic gloves holding a blue metal bottle of capsicum spray behind her back.

items.synopsis: The NT Police Association is among vocal critics of a Northern Territory government plan to give additional powers to security guards, which many say are not adequately trained.

title.children: 'Fraught with danger': Concern over plan to arm NT security guards with capsicum spray

image.altText: A police officer in the foreground walks along a street. A man in a suit and another police officer walk behind him

items.synopsis: Northern Territory Police will begin implementing a new approach to domestic and family violence in response to a months-long inquest into the deaths of four women at the hands of their partners.

title.children: 'I can't see a way out': NT Police to overhaul domestic violence response, inquest hears

image.altText: A composite image of an Aboriginal woman wearing a black hat and a white woman with brown hair

items.synopsis: Cancer survival rates in Australia are some of the highest in the world, but many people, including Indigenous Australians and those living in regional areas, are falling far behind.

title.children: More than 160,000 Australians are expected to be diagnosed with cancer this year. But the outcomes for some will vary greatly

image.altText: a bushfire at night, with the whole scene lit up red, sparks flying.

items.synopsis: Cattle producers, firefighters and Indigenous rangers want action to stop deliberately lit fires with more than 13 million hectares burnt in the past two months.

title.children: Fires lit by 'scumbags' have burnt millions of hectares and NT land managers are livid

image.altText: A man sits amongst rubble, his head in his hands.

items.synopsis: Israeli forces claim to have killed another Hamas commander in their second strike on Gaza's largest refugee camp in two days, as a first group of civilian evacuees from Gaza — including 20 Australians — escapes into Egypt.

title.children: Israel claims Hamas commander killed in second strike on Jabalia refugee camp in two days

image.altText: A man crouches on a hospital floor looking at people under silver blankets

items.synopsis: In Gaza's busiest hospital, doctors do what they can to treat a tidal wave of desperate patients injured in Israeli air strikes. WARNING: Some readers might find the details and images in this story distressing.

title.children: Sewing needles, dishwashing liquid and kids on the floor: The unthinkable horrors of Gaza's hospitals

image.altText: The Beatles during a photo session in Twickenham, 9 April 1969

items.synopsis: On the eve of the release of The Beatles' final ever song, created with a little help from AI technology, a new documentary sheds light on the process of making it.

title.children: 'It's like John's here': The process of making The Beatles' final ever song

image.altText: A cross stands on a hill above Santa Teresa as the sun rises.

items.synopsis: A public housing tenant from the remote Central Australian community of Santa Teresa has won a High Court bid to sue her landlord for distress and disappointment over the failure to carry out repairs.

title.children: High Court rules NT Housing liable for impact of lack of repairs on public housing

image.altText: Two men in black caps and blue shirts talk to a person on the street. The photo is shot from a distance through bars.

items.synopsis: Data obtained through Freedom of Information shows most incidents Darwin private security guards responded to in the past year relate to homelessness and alcohol.

title.children: Data shows homelessness, alcohol behind most Darwin private security incidents

image.altText: thndo

items.synopsis: "Chosen family" is the overarching theme of the acclaimed musical Rent, set to make its way around Australia next year. Stars Thndo and Nick Afoa shed light on how they will bring this iconic story to life.

title.children: Rent the musical: We won't have to wait 525,600 minutes for our favourite show to come Australia

image.altText: A white blonde woman and a white brunette man, both in their 30s, stand intimately looking at each other in a desert.

items.synopsis: The third feature from Australian director Garth Davis sets a high dramatic bar for this adaptation of Iain Reid's 2018 novel, but it unintentionally teeters into comedy.

title.children: Saoirse Ronan and Paul Mescal star in this R-rated sci-fi romance filmed in regional Victoria

image.altText: A pile of rapid antigen tests on a white background

items.synopsis: New research suggests manufacturer statements about the accuracy of COVID rapid antigen tests generally 'overstate sensitivity', but experts say it's still important to use them.

title.children: Should we still be using RATs to test for COVID-19? Yes, but choose wisely

image.altText: An F1 driver in orange, holding his helmet in the garage after qualifying

items.synopsis: Oscar Piastri has excelled in sprints in 2023, winning in Qatar and finishing second in Belgium.

title.children: Piastri looking to capitalise on F1 sprint in Brazil after 'reassuring' results

image.altText: A man dressed as Santa wearing a face mask.

items.synopsis: The Director of Communicable Diseases at NSW Health has warned a COVID wave could peak at Christmas for the third year in a row.

title.children: Another 'COVID Christmas' on the cards thanks to fresh wave, experts warn

image.altText: ASX 200 board

items.synopsis: Wall Street's major share indices have rallied after the US Federal Reserve left interest rates on hold for a second straight meeting and traders bet the next move will be a cut sometime next year. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Fed holds rates and financial markets believe it is done, leading shares higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We often include market probabilities of interest rate moves in our coverage previewing central bank meetings. Former RBA economist and now economics lecturer Dr Zac Gross has penned an interesting article on his blog about why some of those market measures may currently be skewed and slightly understating the market odds for a rate hike. "The crux of the issue lies in the contractual language of the interbank cash rate futures the foundation of the ASX's published probabilities," Dr Gross explains. "The cash rate futures pay out according to the value of the cash rate averaged over the calendar month — not what the RBA actually targets the cash rate to be. "Historically the actual cash rate has tracked the target very closely. For instance, if the RBA aims for a cash rate of 4.10%, the monthly average cash rate would typically aligned almost exactly with that 4.10% target. But the introduction of quantitative easing has disrupted this close sure fire aim. The gap between the target cash rate and its actual average opened up during COVID as shown in the bottom panel of the chart below. "The RBA's recent note on this issue highlights that this gap has reduced to an average of 3 basis points and predicts it will eventually revert to zero once quantitative tightening is fully implemented. "This seemingly minor gap of 3 basis points can significantly alter the probabilities when determining the likelihood of a 25 basis point movement in the cash rate, a standard unit for an interest rate adjustment. "Incorporating this spread into the ASX's calculations, the probability shifts from an even 50-50 implied probability to a 65% likelihood of a rate hike ." It is not clear how this affects the Refinitiv and Bloomberg calculations on interest rate probability, typically used by us at the ABC, and which themselves usually differ slightly between each other. You can read Zac's full post on his blog .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rate rise odds may be slightly higher than some market measures suggest

children.content: We often include market probabilities of interest rate moves in our coverage previewing central bank meetings.
Former RBA economist and now economics lecturer Dr Zac Gross
has penned an
interesting article on his blog
about why some of those market measures may currently be skewed and slightly understating the market odds for a rate hike.
"The crux of the issue lies in the contractual language of the interbank cash rate futures the foundation of the ASX's published probabilities," Dr Gross explains.
"The cash rate futures pay out according to the value of the cash rate averaged over the calendar month — not what the RBA actually targets the cash rate to be.

"Historically the actual cash rate has tracked the target very closely. For instance, if the RBA aims for a cash rate of 4.10%, the monthly average cash rate would typically aligned almost exactly with that 4.10% target. But the introduction of quantitative easing has disrupted this close sure fire aim.
The gap between the target cash rate and its actual average opened up during COVID
as shown in the bottom panel of the chart below.

props.alt: A gap between the cash rate and the cash rate target opened up during COVID

children.content: A gap between the cash rate and the cash rate target opened up during COVID
(RBA)

"The RBA's recent note on this issue highlights that this gap has reduced to an average of 3 basis points and predicts it will eventually revert to zero once quantitative tightening is fully implemented.

"This seemingly minor gap of 3 basis points can significantly alter the probabilities when determining the likelihood of a 25 basis point movement in the cash rate, a standard unit for an interest rate adjustment.
"Incorporating this spread into the ASX's calculations,
the probability shifts from an even 50-50 implied probability to a 65% likelihood of a rate hike
It is not clear how this affects the
Refinitiv and Bloomberg calculations on interest rate probability
, typically used by us at the ABC, and which themselves usually differ slightly between each other.
You can read Zac's full post
on his blog

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has used a speech in Melbourne to clarify comments which were interpreted as putting pressure on the Reserve Bank about its upcoming interest rate decision next Tuesday. Mr Chalmers responded to last week's Consumer Price Index (CPI) by saying it hadn't "materially" altered the outlook for inflation. That was the day after RBA governor Michele Bullock had delivered a speech at a Commonwealth Bank hosted event saying: "The board will not hesitate to rate the cash rate further if there is a material upward revision to the outlook for inflation." But this morning Mr Chalmers said he was referring to Treasury forecasts about inflation, which had not changed significantly after the latest CPI data, while the Reserve Bank is independent and will arrive at its own set of forecasts. "Treasury was already preparing for a modest revision of the near-term inflation forecasts before last week's new numbers, recognising the upward pressure which came from earlier decisions by global oil producers to wind back supply," Mr Chalmers told the audience at the beginning of a speech that was otherwise about the clean energy transition. "In particular, global oil prices have remained higher than Treasury had expected since the end of the September quarter. "Combined with the escalating conflict in the Middle East, this means that inflation is likely to be more volatile in the near term. " But there was nothing additional or unexpected in the September quarter CPI which materially altered Treasury's expectations for when inflation will return to the target band. "Which is why I said the September quarter result didn't represent a material change to Treasury's outlook for inflation – While being really careful not to speak for the Reserve Bank, which will come to its own view on the outlook for inflation, independently and appropriately and in time. "That independence is important, which is why I'm implementing the RBA Review recommendations which seek to strengthen it." Mr Chalmers said he has a constructive relationship with the new RBA governor, who he appointed in July to take over the role when Philip Lowe's term ended in September. " The Governor and I talk regularly, we met again on Tuesday – "And we've been working closely together: bedding down the response to the RBA Review; renewing our approach to full employment; ensuring fiscal and monetary policy are complementary, not in conflict."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chalmers says 'no material change' comments related to Treasury inflation forecasts

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers
has used a speech in Melbourne to clarify comments which were interpreted as putting pressure on the Reserve Bank about its upcoming interest rate decision next Tuesday.
Mr Chalmers responded to last week's
Consumer Price Index (CPI)
by saying it hadn't "materially" altered the outlook for inflation.
That was the day after
RBA governor Michele Bullock
had delivered a speech
at a Commonwealth Bank hosted event saying:
"The board will not hesitate to rate the cash rate further if there is a material upward revision to the outlook for inflation."

But this morning Mr Chalmers said he was referring to Treasury forecasts about inflation, which had not changed significantly after the latest CPI data, while the Reserve Bank is independent and will arrive at its own set of forecasts.

"Treasury was already preparing for a modest revision of the near-term inflation forecasts before last week's new numbers, recognising the upward pressure which came from earlier decisions by global oil producers to wind back supply," Mr Chalmers told the audience at the beginning of a speech that was otherwise about the clean energy transition.
"In particular, global oil prices have remained higher than Treasury had expected since the end of the September quarter.
"Combined with the escalating conflict in the Middle East, this means that inflation is likely to be more volatile in the near term.
But there was nothing additional or unexpected in the September quarter CPI which materially altered Treasury's expectations for when inflation will return to the target band

"Which is why I said the September quarter result didn't represent a material change to Treasury's outlook for inflation – While being really careful not to speak for the Reserve Bank, which will come to its own view on the outlook for inflation, independently and appropriately and in time.
"That independence is important, which is why I'm implementing the RBA Review recommendations which seek to strengthen it."
Mr Chalmers said he has a constructive relationship with the new RBA governor,
who he appointed in July
to take over the role when Philip Lowe's term ended in September.
The Governor and I talk regularly, we met again on Tuesday

"And we've been working closely together: bedding down the response to the RBA Review; renewing our approach to full employment; ensuring fiscal and monetary policy are complementary, not in conflict."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB's senior economist, markets, Taylor Nugent, has been across the Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments, here's the highlights. "In the Q & A, Powell said the FOMC [Federal Open Market Committee] is 'proceeding carefully' and that evidence of above potential growth could warrant a hike. "He also said that the FOMC was attentive to the increase in longer term yields, but agreed with a questioner that tighter conditions are not yet sufficient to 'finish the job'. "Powell said the FOMC was monitoring geopolitics for economic implications, (this didn't make it into the post-meeting statement). "Powell was clear that the Committee was not thinking or talking about rate cuts, adding that the question is 'should we hike more'. "The OIS curve has shifted lower with only 3.5bps of tightening priced for December and a cumulative 90bps of cuts for next year versus 82bps priced before the decision and press conference ." What that tells you is that, even though the FOMC may not be talking about rate cuts yet, the market certainly is, and expects three or four of them next year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fed 'proceeding carefully' but not yet thinking about rate cuts, says Powell

children.content: NAB's senior economist, markets, Taylor Nugent
, has been across the
Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments
, here's the highlights.
"In the Q
A, Powell said the FOMC [Federal Open Market Committee] is
'proceeding carefully'
and that evidence of
above potential growth could warrant a hike
"He also said that the FOMC was attentive to the increase in longer term yields, but agreed with a questioner that tighter conditions are not yet sufficient to 'finish the job'.
"Powell said the FOMC was monitoring geopolitics for economic implications, (this didn't make it into the post-meeting statement).
"Powell was clear that
the Committee was not thinking or talking about rate cuts
, adding that the question is 'should we hike more'.
"The OIS curve has shifted lower with only 3.5bps of tightening priced for December and
a cumulative 90bps of cuts for next year versus 82bps priced before the decision and press conference
What that tells you is that, even though the FOMC may not be talking about rate cuts yet, the market certainly is, and expects three or four of them next year.

image.altText: Two men walking away from cameras outside County Court in Melbourne

items.synopsis: Neo-Nazi Jacob Hersant is expected to be charged on summons after allegedly making a Nazi salute outside court in Melbourne last week.

title.children: Melbourne man to be charged with making a Nazi salute under new laws, police say

image.altText: Shade sail worker Kane McLatchie works outside during a heatwave

items.synopsis: As extreme weather events become more frequent, a new report from the nation's key agency for information and statistics on Australia's health and welfare unpacks the impacts.

title.children: Older people, men and Queenslanders among most susceptible to extreme weather related injury, new data shows

image.altText: A woman in a dark top, standing outside in a garden, holding papers

items.synopsis: The central bank insists housing is still a topic of intense focus, as rents and prices rocket, despite a key analysis group within the RBA not meeting for more than a year.

title.children: Property is white hot and the RBA is changing the way it examines the market

image.altText: Ian Smith (1)

items.synopsis: For years, sperm donors believed their identity would remain secret, but the explosion of online DNA databases changed everything, writes Ian Smith.

title.children: My seven biological kids via sperm donation were never meant to know me — but everything's changed

image.altText: Seen from behind, a young person with singlet and hair tied in bun sits on a bed in slightly dark room facing a large window.

items.synopsis: One in three 18 to 19-year-olds in Australia has experienced intimate partner violence in the last 12 months. These young people's experiences show what might help.

title.children: Many Australian teens experience abuse from their partner. But few recognise it as domestic violence

image.altText: A woman in a wheelchair at a specialised gym for people with multiple sclerosis.

items.synopsis: As a person with multiple sclerosis, Meg knows "moving is the thing that keeps you going". In her home state, where rates for the disease are the highest in Australia, a new centre has opened to help her and others do that and more.

title.children: With MS, doing nothing is not an option for Meg — she has to keep moving

image.altText: Rose wine being poured from a bottle into a wine glass. Only the hand of the person pouring it is visible.

items.synopsis: A recent health survey has reignited the push for health warnings to be introduced on alcohol packaging, but boutique wine producers say their products aren't the problem when it comes to problem drinking.

title.children: 'We don't want to be the fun police,' but doctors say large health warnings for alcohol are needed

image.altText: A female footballer wearing gold, running away in celebration, smiling, after scoring

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr and Mary Fowler steal the show as the Matildas stamp their class over a determined Chinese Taipei side.

title.children: The Matildas now know who they'll have to beat to book their ticket to the Paris Olympics

image.altText: Two men wearing caps and  blue shirts with 'TPS security' walk away from the camera down a city laneway. People sit nearby.

items.synopsis: The NT government says it needs to fund private security firms in Darwin to keep public order, but the Police Association is warning it's risking deaths.

title.children: 'Someone's going to be killed': NT Police Association warning over private security guards

image.altText: Matt Barker and Grace Tame watch another man speak at a press conference

items.synopsis: The term "landmark case" gets bandied around a lot, but the importance of GLJ v The Trustees of the Diocese of Lismore to survivors of institutional child sexual abuse cannot be overstated, writes Louise Milligan.

title.children: A landmark case opens the door for thousands of sexual abuse survivors — and lawyers are already firing off letters

image.altText: A woman holds a baby.

items.synopsis: A number of Australian families in Gaza have been told to head to the Rafah border crossing with Egypt if it is safe to do so, as it opens for foreign nationals.

title.children: 'Seize this opportunity': Australian families in Gaza told to head to Rafah as border crossing opens

image.altText: A male cricketer in a green and gold shirt, green helmet, in the follow through of a swing

items.synopsis: Glenn Maxwell is under concussion protocols for up to eight days after his second freak accident in the past year.

title.children: Maxwell to miss World Cup clash with England after falling from golf cart

image.altText: Marcia Langton wears a bright red coat and gives a small smile to the camera.

items.synopsis: Professor Marcia Langton was called as an expert witness to the ongoing coronial inquest into the deaths of four Indigenous women in the NT.

title.children: Marcia Langton fronts NT domestic violence inquest, calls for 'no exceptions' alcohol restrictions

image.altText: A man in a lab coat standing in a white room next to a small bar fridge, making a thumbs down gesture

items.synopsis: Consumer advocacy group CHOICE calls out "the very worst products and services" it found this year.

title.children: This fridge 'doesn't make things cold'. It's won a Shonky Award, just like Coles and Woolworths

image.altText: Sign for St Lucy's School for children with disabilities in Wahroonga, Sydney.

items.synopsis: A recovery operation is continuing after the 10-year-old boy died at the scene on Cleveland Street in Wahroonga.

title.children: Boy dies after being trapped under a school lift on Sydney's upper North Shore

image.altText: A man in a white button-up shirt walking with a tree and building behind him.

items.synopsis: Kerrod James Frahm had a "duty of care to protect his son" before the 11-year-old died of a brown snake bite in 2021, magistrate says.

title.children: Court rules father 'had knowledge of alleged snakebite' before his son died

image.altText: a herd of horses in waters

items.synopsis: A local MP whose electorate includes Kosciuszko National Park defends a recent NSW government decision to allow aerial shooting of feral horses, during a budget estimates hearing.

title.children: 'On an excursion, maybe?': Concerns children will see dead brumbies once Kosciuszko aerial cull begins

image.altText: Firefighters battling a grassfire at the side of a road

items.synopsis: The bushfire threat continues for Queensland and NSW, but authorities hope favourable weather conditions will help control fires throughout the day.

title.children: NSW town 'literally surrounded by fires', as Queensland homes destroyed in blazes
